affiliations.id: University at Albany (State University of New York)
affiliations.name: University at Albany (State University of New York)

children.value: to reproduce style of visualization used in the New York Times article
In the Atlantic Ocean, Subtle Shifts Hint at Dramatic Dangers
Open an Intake catalogue reference Sea Surface Height data
Make a geographic map of the data using ipyleaflet

from ipyleaflet import Map, TileLayer, basemaps
from ipyleaflet.velocity import Velocity
from intake import open_catalog
is a large repository of ocean products including in-situ observations, satellite based remote sensing data, and numerical model output.
We want to look at altimeter satellite data to show the Sea Level Anomalies (SLA) for the global ocean. The particular data product is called
Global Ocean Gridded L4 Sea Surface Heights and Derived Variables Reprocessed (1993-Ongoing)
This dataset is available as an analysis-ready on the Pangeo Cloud Data Catalog
This dataset is marked “requester pays” which means we have do an addtional step if we are not already on Pangeo Hub on the Google Cloud Platform.
Several of the datasets within the Pangeo cloud data catalog are contained in

storage buckets. This means that a user requesting data must provide their own billing project (created and authenticated through Google Cloud Platform) to be billed for the charges associated with accessing a dataset. To set up an GCP billing project and use it for authentication in applications:
; if this is the first time using GCP, a prompt will appear to choose a Google account to link to all GCP-related activities.

role to your account, which enables it to make billed requests on the behalf of the project.
Through command line, install the
; this can be done using conda:

command line interface, logging into the account used to create the aforementioned project and selecting it as the default project; this will allow the project to be used for requester pays access through the command line:
to establish application default credentials; this will allow the project to be used for requester pays access through applications:

children.value:
center = [35, -50]
zoom = 4
m = Map(center=center, zoom=zoom, interpolation='nearest', basemap=basemaps.Gaode.Satellite)

display_options = {
    'velocityType': 'Global Wind',
    'displayPosition': 'bottomleft',
    'displayEmptyString': 'No wind data'
}

wind = Velocity(
    data=ds.isel(time=-1), 
    zonal_speed='ugos', meridional_speed='vgos', 
    latitude_dimension='latitude', longitude_dimension='longitude', 
    velocity_scale=0.2, max_velocity=1, 
    display_options=display_options
)

m.add_layer(wind)

m
In this example we loaded sea level data from an analysis-ready cloud based dataset and made a visualization of that data using mapping library.
This notebook is based on the Pangeo physical oceanography gallery example:
